occurrences.line_text: After that they againe returned beene,
They in that Gardin planted be againe;
Or sent into the chaungefull world againe,
To bring her backe againe, or worke her finall bale.
But when he stayd, to flight againe she did her take.
And was return'd againe vnto his Dame,
May meet againe, and each take happie chance.
With that same Squyre, returned backe againe
Your zealous hast, till morrow next againe
And Troy againe out of her dust was reard,
Tho when againe he him bethought to liue,
But when againe he backward cast his eye,
Euer to come into his clouch againe,
Till we returne againe in safetie:
She turned her, and returned backe againe:
And she receiu'd againe to bed and bord,
And downe againe himselfe disdainefully
Once to me yold, not to be yold againe:
Againe, when as the Troiane boy so faire
And when they ceast, it gan againe to play,
Tho blinding him againe, his way he forth did take.
When that same Maske againe should forth arize.
Till that againe the second euening
Which wrought it, could the same recure againe.
That one did make, the other mard againe,
Them reconcyld againe, and to their homes did driue.
Againe he droue at him with double might,
But when the floud is spent, then backe againe
And eft them turned both againe to fight;
That neither could in hast themselues againe vpreare.
They vp againe them selues can lightly reare,
The last day came, when all those knightes againe
Whence litle lust he had to rise againe.
That all the wretched world recomforteth againe.
The belt againe, about her bodie gan it tie.
And oft in wrath he thence againe vprose;
And oft in wrath he layd him downe againe.
And as his hand he vp againe did reare,
Yet she it forst to haue againe vpheld,
And eft againe deuiz'd some what to say,
She almost fell againe into a swound,
Which she long listning, softly askt againe
Vnto those woods he turned backe againe,
And him restore to former grace againe.
His weary eie returnd to him againe,
But swaru'd aside, and there againe did stay;
She follow'd her, and thought againe it to assay.
Till she drew neare, and then againe remoue;
And him receiu'd againe to former fauours state.
In Princes Court doe hap to sprout againe,
But when he to himselfe returnd againe,
But ere his hand he could recure againe,
Which neuer they recouer might againe;
Againe some other, that in hard assaies
And wish to life return'd againe to bee,
And him restor'd to healthfull state againe:
Should fetch againe, and finally destroy
Had drenched them, he drowned him againe;
But soone he gan such folly to forthinke againe.
Oft listening if he mote her heare againe;
Therefore to Tryphon she againe doth hast,
And by what markes may he be knowne againe?
By which it's easie him to know againe,
But ere he could him selfe recure againe,
How she was found againe, and spousde to Marinell.
He would to his owne part restore the same againe.
Therefore leaue off to weigh them all againe,
And as they were, them equalize againe.
And by him brought againe to Faerie land;
So backe he brought Sir Marinell againe;
Whom hauing quickly arm'd againe anew,
Which when he had perform'd, then backe againe
So backe againe they homeward turnd their feete.
Yet with her shield she warded it againe,
Vpon her helmet he againe her strooke,
And to her turning, thus began againe;
So fond a lesson, as to loue againe.
Till thou haue tride againe, & tempted him more neare.
But the false mayden shortly turn'd againe
She fayn'd to count the time againe anew,
And then againe resolu'd to hunt him out
Till she againe thus sayd; Talus be bold,
And then againe she did her selfe torment,
She vnto Talus forth return'd againe,
The loft was raysd againe, that no man could it spie.
To make new warre against the Gods againe:
And them repaide againe with double more.
Stayd not, till she came to her selfe againe,
Against him made againe. So both anon
But when againe they had recouered sence,
Againe the Pagan threw another dart,
And made him backe againe as fast to fly;
That backe againe vpon themselues they turned,
But when as he would to a snake againe
Her selfe eftsoones she gan conuert againe;
Now rise againe, at this your ioyous sight.
And sodainely t'auenge him selfe againe,
Eftsoones againe his axe he raught on hie,
That earst was dead, restor'd to life againe,
That forst her turne againe in her despight,
But ere that it she backe againe had borne,
Now turne againe (Sir Artegall then sayd)
My former shield I may resume againe:
Which Burbon seeing, her againe assayd,
And to his voyage gan againe proceed:
That by no meanes it backe againe he forth could wrast.
Againe whiles he him saw so ill bested,
And there arriu'd againe, whence forth he set,
And all the aire rebellowed againe.
And to your selfe doe it returne againe:
Refused hath to yeeld her loue againe,
But Calidore vprose againe full light,
And ere he could recouer foot againe,
But gaue them streight vnto that Squire againe,
He now againe is on his former way,
The law of armes; yet breake it should againe,
And me in lieu thereof reuil'd againe,
His scornefull taunts vnto his teeth againe,
That the faint sprite he did reuoke againe,
And with mad mood againe vpon him flew,
That from his steed him nigh he drew againe.
He wearie woxe, and backe return'd againe
Recured well, and made him whole againe:
So hauing all his bands againe vptyde,
He with him thought backe to returne againe:
All is in time like to returne againe
Vowing, that neuer he in bed againe
After that Timias had againe recured
And of her grace did stand againe assured,
To whom the Squire nought aunswered againe,
That soone as he returned backe againe,
It euer can recured be againe;
Bidding him turne againe, false traytour knight,
Did slay againe, as ye may see there in the stound.
Gathered him selfe together soone againe,
Ere she againe to Calepine was brought;
And to requite him with the like againe,
Rebeaten backe vpon him selfe againe,
And least he should recouer foote againe,
But all is now repayd with interest againe.
But being vp, he lookt againe aloft,
Now turne againe my teme thou iolly swayne,
Surely my sonne (then answer'd he againe)
Tho backe returning to my sheepe againe,
I shal resolue, or backe to turne againe,
Whom by no meanes thou canst recall againe;
Mote him auaile, but to returne againe
Or sold againe. Now when faire Pastorell
And bringeth backe againe.
To call the soule backe to her home againe;
But when they saw her now reliu'd againe,
But askt againe, what ment that rufull hew;
Mongst which the theeues them questioned againe,
That long had lyen dead, and made againe aliue.
But now I come into my course againe,
And Bellamour againe so well her pleased,
But closing it againe like as before,
The same againe if now ye list to haue,
And liuest thou my daughter now againe?
And fierce assailing forst him turne againe:
Sternely he turnd againe, when he him strooke
And got into the world at liberty againe.
So now he raungeth through the world againe,
Against an hill, ne might from labour lin;
Which shielded them against the boyling heat,
Against my liking backe, to doe you grace:
What iustice can but iudge against thee right,
Against the day of wrath, to burden thee?
Against spirituall foes, yeelds by and by,
Ne I against the same can iustly preace:
To tell, were as to striue against the streame.
Against her snowy brest he fiercely bent,
Against his praise to stirre vp enmitye
That streight against that knight his speare he did addresse.
Whiles cursed steele against that badge I bent,
A knight had wrought against a Ladie gent;
The eldest did against the youngest goe,
And both against the middest meant to worken woe.
And dayly warre against his foeman moues,
Against themselues turning their wrathfull spight,
Do arme your selfe against that day, them to confound.
Against him bent, and fiercely did menace:
Against him turning all his fell intent,
That thee against me drew with so impetuous dread.
Against Pyrrochles, and new matter framed
Against foule feends to aide vs millitant?
Against his foe and mine: watch thou I pray;
The same to thee, against his lord to fight,
That doth against the dead his hand vpreare,
Against the Pagans brest, and therewith thought
Against two foes of so exceeding might,
Against that knight: Harrow and well away,
Against the viaundes should be ministred.
Did head against them make, and strong munificence.
Through proud ambition, against her rebeld,
Then made he head against his enimies,
Against the forreine Morands he exprest;
Yet oft the Briton kings against them strongly swayd.
With whom she marched streight against her foes,
Triumphed oft against her enimis;
Against the fort of reason euermore
Seuen of the same against the Castle gate,
Against the fiue great Bulwarkes of that pile,
Those same against the bulwarke of the Sight
Their wicked engins they against it bent:
All those against that fort did bend their batteries.
Against the fourth Bulwarke, that is the Tast,
Against that same fift bulwarke they continued fight.
Against that Castle restlesse siege did lay,
For her defence, against that Carle to fight,
And crusht his carkasse so against his brest,
And gaue against his mother earth a gronefull sownd.
That it rebounds against the lowly plaine,
Against this lifelesse shadow so to fight:
And bent his dreadfull speare against the others head.
Ne armes to beare against the others syde:
Fierce battell against one, with cruell might and maine.
And fell intent against the virgin sheene:
But lou'd their natiue flesh against all kind,
Against it strongly striue, and yield thee not,
Against their forrein foe, that comes from farre,
Against his Saxon foes in bloudy field to fight.
Against the good king Oswald, who indewd
Thus warreid he long time against his will,
And woxe halfe wroth against her damzels slacke,
Warre against heauen, and heaped hils on hight,
Against the silly clowne, who dead through feare,
Makes the huge element against her kind
Against that Castles Lord they gan conspire,
Against that nation, from whose race of old
Yet durst he not against it doe or say,
Battell against the Gods? so we a God inuade.
Against that Knight, ere he him well could torne
Against all those, that chalenge it to gard,
Against Cambello fiercely him addrest;
Against so many no lesse mightie met,
Against the Turneiment which is not long.
And him against Sir Blandamour did ride
But none of them against his strokes could stand,
That none against them battell durst maintaine.
Chaufing and foming choler each against his fo.
That almost had against you trespassed this day.
Gan fewter, and against her fiercely ran.
Against her rode, full of despiteous ire,
Against the course of kind, ne meruaile nought,
Then haue they all themselues against me bent:
Against all hard mishaps and fortunelesse misfare.
Against the stones and trees did rayle anew,
Against those two let driue, as they were wood:
Whose office was, against all manner wights
And her against sweet Cherefulnesse was placed,
And her against sate comely Curtesie,
Both girlonds of his Saints against their foes offence.
Against the storme of euery dreadfull stoure:
Who sore against his will did him retaine,
Against the Picts, that swarmed ouer all,
Her siluer feet, faire washt against this day:
Against the Titans, that whylome rebelled
Against that cruell Tyrant, which opprest
Nor powr of charms, which she against him wrought,
For wight, against his powre them selues to reare:
And them against came all that list to giust,
Against them durst his head to perill shew.
That iudgement so vniust against him had ordayned.
And bent against them selues their cruell hands.
That he mote fresher be against the next daies fight.
But he that helpe from her against her will discarded.
Against her Knight, for being so vntrew;
With inward griefe and malice did against them swell.
To make new warre against the Gods againe:
Succour against her greedy enimy:
Against him made againe. So both anon
Suffring my hand against my heart to stray:
He either spoiles, if they against him stand,
To Iustice, and against her still doth fight,
To haue bene done against her Lady Queene,
Which she against the dred Mercilla oft did frame.
Against her brought, to banish all remorse,
And with him to make part against her, came
Many graue persons, that against her pled;
For zeale of Iustice was against her bent.
Against Duessa, damned by them all;
Her to defend against all forrein foes,
That should their powre against her right oppose.
For ayde, against that cruell Tyrants theft,
And leueld all against one certaine place,
T'oppose against his powre, he forth issued
Against his Gods, and fire to them did threat,
Against him iustifie, and proue her cleare
Against these pesants, which haue me opprest,
And grinning griesly, did against him weld
For little bootes against him hand to reare.
Against him stoutly ran, as nought afeard,
Vouchsafe to reskue her against a Knight,
In lustlesse wise, as if against his will,
Against an armed knight, that did on horsebacke ryde.
Against both which that knight wrought knightlesse shame.
To rayse a lyuing blame against the dead:
And with presumpteous powre against that knight streight go'th.
Against her Knight, her gentlenesse refused,
Did shut the gate against him in his face,
Against his foe that did him so pursew:
He lent against a tree, that backeward onset bard.
Did front him face to face against him bent,
And him against his powre gan to prepare;
Against him ran; but th'one did misse his marke,
Whereat much grieu'd against that straunger knight,
Against the heauen in order battailous,
Abusde, against all reason and all law,
Least they should ioyne against the weaker side,
Or rise against the remnant at their will;
Against his will fast bound in yron chaine,
Was sent to Aganip of Celtica.
They are accorded: Agape
Her name was Agape whose children werne
Or other griesly thing, that him agast.
To moue, and tremble as it were agast,
That made him stagger, and stand halfe agast
Wondred Agaue, Poris, and Nesï¿½a,
And his foe fettred would release agayne,
But if it should not grieue you, backe agayne
That made the sparckling waues to smoke agayne,
And hauing ympt the head to it agayne,
And to her kingdomes seat restore agayne;
Did wisely make, and good Agdistes call:
He in the first flowre of my freshest age,
Haue slaine him straight: but when he sees his age,
Feare, sicknesse, age, losse, labour, sorrow, strife,
She was a woman in her freshest age,
And through great age had lost their kindly sight,
Which to late age were neuer mentioned.
But that fiers fate did crop the blossome of his age.
It was my fortune commune to that age,
Weake hands, but counsell is most strong in age.
And leaue the rudenesse of that antique age
That with thy brutenesse shendst thy comely age,
And in the flowre now of her freshest age;
He Steward was hight Diet; rype of age,
There sate a man of ripe and perfect age,
At last ripe age bad him surrender late
To have diuided. Tho when feeble age
Three sonnes he dying left, all vnder age;
For soone comes age, that will her pride deflowre:
As if that age bad him that burden spare,
Let later age that noble vse enuie,
But went her way; ne her vnguilty age
The comfort of her age and weary dayes,
Now in the blossome of his freshest age:
In stead thereof sweet peace and quiet age
That needed much her weake age to desire,
And eke that age despysed nicenesse vaine,
But antique age yet in the infancie
And Neso, and Eione well in age,
When as mans age was in his freshest prime,
For from the golden age, that first was named,
Her name was Belgï¿½, who in former age
Of which though present age doe plenteous seeme,
But now weake age had dimd his candle light.
So long as age enabled him thereto,
But being now attacht with timely age,
Wasting the strength of her immortall age.
To future age of her this mention may be made.
An aged Sire, in long blacke weedes yclad,
(Quoth then that aged man;) the way to win
But hardly was restreined of that aged sire.
Weary of aged Tithones saffron bed,
Then bowing downe her aged backe, she kist
And aged limbs on Cypresse stadle stout,
That downe he tombled; as an aged tree,
He was an aged syre, all hory gray,
That aged Dame, the Ladie of the place:
Then said the aged Coelia, Deare dame,
Wherein an aged holy man did lye,
There they do finde that godly aged Sire,
Most trew, then said the holy aged man;
Faire ympe of Phoebus, and his aged bride,
It could recure, and aged long decay
Of aged Tithone gan her selfe to reare,
That aged Sire, the Lord of all that land,
Forth came that auncient Lord and aged Queene,
Least his long way his aged limbes should tire:
By this his aged guide in presence came;
And that same Hag, his aged mother, hight
Vnto an aged woman, poore and bare,
Ne gaue him leaue to bid that aged sire
And them beside an aged Sire did trace,
Crau'd leaue of Alma, and that aged sire,
Their aged Syre, thus eased of his crowne,
Till aged Hely by dew heritage it gaynd.
And him beside an aged Squire there rode,
Her aged Nurse, whose name was Glauce hight,
But th'aged Nurse her calling to her bowre,
Then it had lighted on an aged Oke;
An aged sire with head all frory hore,
From aged Mnemon; for my wits bene light.
The aged Dame him seeing so enraged,
Through that false witch, and that foule aged dreuill,
And that old aged Dame, his faithfull Squire,
And with him eke that aged Squire attone;
In which old Styx her aged bones alway,
Next came the aged Ocean, and his Dame,
But much more aged was his wife then he,
Yet seem'd full aged by his outward sight,
An aged wight, wayfaring all alone,
But being aged now and weary to
Then came to them a good old aged syre,
And of his aged Beldame homely well;
His aged wife, with many others wide:
Is to be wise, and ware of like agein.
Great Belus, Phoeax, and Agenor best;
With natures pen, in ages graue degree,
Yet haue from wisest ages hidden beene:
But later ages pride, like corn-fed steed,
The wisest men, I weene, that liued in their ages.
Three ages, such as mortall men contriue,
And things foregone through many ages held,
Of warlike puissaunce in ages spent,
Which who so list looke backe to former ages,
It hath bene through all ages euer seene,
There Florimell in her first ages flowre
Of kindnesse and of curteous aggrace;
And that, which all faire workes doth most aggrace,
Him to aggrate, and greatest pleasures shew;
And each one sought his Lady to aggrate:
Or that may dayntiest fantasie aggrate,
But Palmer, if it mote thee so aggrate,
Pleasure, that doth both gods and men aggrate,
And tyde behind his charet, to aggrate
She litle answer'd him, but lightly did aggrate.
What euer thing he did her to aggrate,
Would hardly find to aggrauate her griefe;
And aggrauate the horror of her blame.
Who nought aghast, his mightie hand enhaunst:
As one aghast with feends or damned sprights,
The fearefull Shepheard often there aghast
And damned sprights sent forth to make ill men aghast.
With dread whereof his chasing steedes aghast,
There him he finds all sencelesse and aghast,
In senselesse dreame; which sight at first him sore aghast.
At sight whereof the people stand aghast:
Or other accident, which him aghast;
Neither of idle shewes, nor of false charmes aghast.
Carried with wings of feare, like fowle aghast,
That with the souse thereof full sore aghast,
They from the wall him seeing so aghast,
But forst him gape and gaspe, with dread aghast,
And eke the Ladie fearefully aghast,
With noise whereof the Squire now nigh aghast,
He lightly started vp like one aghast,
With drearie drouping eyne lookt vp like one aghast.
In dreadfull darknesse dreadfully aghast;
Next faire Aglaia, last Thalia merry:
And on his head an hood with aglets sprad,
Which long agoe he taken had in hond:
Which with the rest they tooke not long agoe,
Feele my heart perst with so great agonie,
In this distressed doubtfull agonie,
Him to beguile of griefe and agony:
That death were better, then such agony,
That with great sorrow and sad agony,
Full of sad feare, and doubtfull agony,
Ne stayd his flight, nor fearefull agony,
When oblique Saturne sate in the house of agonyes.
She graunted, and that knight so much agraste,
That with his glistring armes does ill agree;
So both agree their bodies to engraue;
Let vs soone hence depart. They soone agree;
Whereto he drew in haste it to agree.
Birdes, voyces, instruments, windes, waters, all agree.
It pleased well. So well they both agree;
Him seemed more their manner did agree;
They all agree, and forward them addrest:
(The harder it to make them well agree)
doth their long strife agree.
So mortall foes so friendly to agree,
With guilefull loue did secretly agree,
Yet ouerrul'd at last, he did to me agree.
Why should they not likewise in loue agree,
And iudge, whether with truth or falshood they agree.
That with this present treatise doth agree,
Agree to goe with her, and by the way,
To see her Ladie, as they did agree.
That all in spight and malice did agree,
They fell to daunce: then did they all agree,
The which were armed both agreeably,
Both clad in shepheards weeds agreeably,
That they to peace agreed. So all was pacifide.
So diff'ring both in willes, agreed in fine:
So all agreed through sweete diuersitie,
So goodly all agreed, they forth yfere did ryde.
At last they both agreed, her seeming grieued
They bene agreed, and to the gates they goe
Agreed to trauell, and their fortunes try.
They all agreed: so turning all to game,
For saluage wight, and thereto well agreed
This being ended thus, and all agreed,
They all agreed, and then that snowy Mayd
So both to wreake their wrathes on Britomart agreed.
Betwixt the Medway and the Thames agreed.
So both agreed, that this their bridale feast
